Milverton knew that Jabez Wilson, a simple-minded pawnbroker, would be captivated by the spectacle and the promise of a job, perhaps even as a ticket seller or a helper. Once Wilson was lured into the circus grounds, the plan was to spring the trap, using the tunnel to transport him away from the scene without a trace, leaving no evidence of foul play. The circus would provide the perfect cover for such a nefarious operation, with its constant noise, movement, and distractions. The criminals would have to act swiftly, ensuring that Wilson was taken before the show ended, before the crowds dispersed and any suspicions were raised. The success of the plan relied on meticulous timing and the complicity of those involved in the circus operations, from the ringmaster down to the lowliest of performers. Only then could they hope to eliminate Jabez Wilson without drawing unwanted attention to their nefarious deeds.

en_results_raw: My intention was to spare him the embarrassment, understanding the social dynamics of the workplace during that era. However, he insisted on maintaining the secrecy of the correspondence, which I respected. I recalled how in those days, personal matters were often kept private, especially when involving the opposite sex. The typewriter, a relatively new invention, was becoming more common in offices, yet it was still a tool that marked one's work with a distinct mechanical rhythm, different from the handwritten letters that had been the norm. I began typing, the keys clicking rhythmically under my fingers, each letter and space meticulously placed on the page. The sound of the typewriter filled the small, somewhat cramped office, a stark contrast to the quiet hum of the larger office space outside our door. As I typed, I imagined the words taking shape, transforming from abstract thoughts into concrete sentences, each one a piece of a larger puzzle of his life. The letters were addressed with care, the names and locations chosen with precision, ensuring they would reach their intended recipients without delay. I included the date at the top, a small but necessary detail that completed the formal structure of the correspondence. As I worked, I couldn't help but wonder about the stories behind these letters, the emotions and circumstances that prompted their writing. Each keystroke was a piece of a narrative I was helping to construct, a narrative that was not mine to tell but mine to help convey. Once the last letter was typed, I placed them all carefully into an envelope, sealing them with a stamp that bore the image of the reigning monarch. The task was complete, but the thoughts it stirred lingered. I had been an accomplice to a secret, a silent partner in a dance of words and emotions, all conducted with the utmost discretion and care.

en_first_half: “He was a very shy man, Mr. Holmes. He would rather walk with me in the evening than in the daylight, for he said that he hated to be conspicuous. Very retiring and gentlemanly he was. Even his voice was gentle. He’d had the quinsy and swollen glands
en_second_half: when he was young, he told me, and it had left him with a weak throat, and a hesitating, whispering fashion of speech. He was always well dressed, very neat and plain, but his eyes were weak, just as mine are, and he wore tinted glasses against the glare.”
en_results_raw: of the throat, which had kept him in bed for several weeks. He was a man of very delicate constitution, and the slightest indisposition had a serious effect upon him. His recovery from this attack was slow, and he was still far from robust. His habits were simple and unassuming; he took no wine, scarcely touched spirits, and his meals were of the plainest. He lived alone, save for a solitary landlady who looked after his few wants. His life seemed to be one of quiet routine, unbroken except by his evening walks with me. He had no known enemies, and his business affairs were of a nature so unimportant that they attracted no attention. Yet, despite his unassuming exterior, there was something about him that piqued my interest. His reticence was not that of a simple, uneducated man, but rather one who chose his words with care, concealing depths of thought behind a facade of simplicity. His gentle voice and soft, brown eyes gave nothing away, and his manner was always courteous and deferential. It was this combination of gentility and secrecy that made him an intriguing figure, one that I felt compelled to understand better.

en_first_half: The man sat huddled up in his chair, with his head sunk upon his breast, like one who is utterly crushed. Holmes stuck his feet up
en_second_half: on the corner of the mantelpiece and, leaning back with his hands in his pockets, began talking, rather to himself, as it seemed, than to us.
en_results_raw: and began to rock to and fro, his eyes closed and his face expressing the deepest despondency. The room, which was usually so full of life and the sharp, keen intellect of its master, was now silent and oppressive. The atmosphere seemed to be thick with the weight of unsolved mysteries and the frustration of a mind that could not fathom the depths of the darkness that had descended upon it. The dim light from the gas lamp flickered, casting long shadows across the walls, accentuating the somber mood. Outside, the London fog crept in, enveloping the city in a shroud of mystery and melancholy, mirroring the internal turmoil within the room. Holmes' usually sharp features were slack, his usually animated eyes closed in resignation. The silence was palpable, broken only by the occasional creak of the old wooden floor as Dr. Watson shifted in his seat, watching his friend with a mixture of concern and confusion. He knew Holmes well, knew that his brilliant mind was never at rest, and this unusual display of vulnerability was unsettling. Dr. Watson reached out a hand, hesitating for a moment before gently resting it on Holmes' shoulder. 'Holmes,' he began, his voice soft yet firm, 'whatever it is that troubles you, you know you can speak to me. We've faced darkness together before, and we'll face it again.' His words, though spoken with care, seemed to hang in the air, unheeded for the moment. Holmes remained motionless, lost in his own thoughts, a storm raging behind his closed eyelids. It was a rare moment of weakness, a crack in the stoic facade that Holmes maintained at all times. Dr. Watson knew that whatever had shaken his friend to the core, it would require more than deductive reasoning and logic to unravel. It would demand empathy, understanding, and perhaps a leap of faith into the unknown. As he sat there, watching Holmes, Dr. Watson realized that sometimes, even the greatest minds need to lean on the strength of others, to acknowledge that there are mysteries that extend beyond the grasp of reason and science. The silence continued, a heavy cloak that seemed to press down on both men, until finally, Holmes lifted his head, his eyes meeting Watson's with a glimmer of their usual sharpness. 'Watson,' he began, his voice steady once more, 'it's not a case that has me down. It's something... personal.' The admission hung in the air, a new layer to the complexity of the moment, signaling that the road ahead would be as much about navigating Holmes' inner turmoil as it would be about solving the mysteries that lay outside.

It was a considerable sum, for people in their position, and the loss of it would have made a serious difference. It was worth an effort to preserve it. The daughter was of a good, amiable disposition, but affectionate and warm-hearted in her ways, so that it was evident that with her fair personal advantages, and her little income, she would not be allowed to remain single long. Now her marriage would mean, of course, the loss of a hundred a year, so what does her stepfather do to prevent it? He takes the obvious course
en_second_half: of keeping her at home and forbidding her to seek the company of people of her own age. But soon he found that that would not answer forever. She became restive, insisted upon her rights, and finally announced her positive intention of going to a certain ball. What does her clever stepfather do then? He conceives an idea more creditable to his head than to his heart. With the connivance and assistance of his wife he disguised himself, covered those keen eyes with tinted glasses, masked the face with a moustache and a pair of bushy whiskers, sunk that clear voice into an insinuating whisper, and doubly secure on account of the girl’s short sight, he appears as Mr. Hosmer Angel, and keeps off other lovers by making love himself.”

en_first_half: “Away we went then, and we drove for at least an hour. Colonel Lysander Stark had said that it was only seven miles, but I should think, from the rate that we seemed to go, and from the time that we took, that it must have been nearer twelve. He sat at my side in silence all the time, and I was aware, more than once when I glanced in his direction, that he was looking at me with great intensity. The country roads seem to be not very good in that part of the world, for we lurched and jolted terribly. I tried to look out of the windows to see something of where we were, but they were made of frosted glass, and I could make out nothing save the occasional bright blur
en_second_half: of a passing light. Now and then I hazarded some remark to break the monotony of the journey, but the colonel answered only in monosyllables, and the conversation soon flagged. At last, however, the bumping of the road was exchanged for the crisp smoothness of a gravel-drive, and the carriage came to a stand. Colonel Lysander Stark sprang out, and, as I followed after him, pulled me swiftly into a porch which gaped in front of us. We stepped, as it were, right out of the carriage and into the hall, so that I failed to catch the most fleeting glance of the front of the house. The instant that I had crossed the threshold the door slammed heavily behind us, and I heard faintly the rattle of the wheels as the carriage drove away.

Ông ta ngồi bên cạnh tôi và suốt chặng đường chẳng hề mở miệng, cứ mỗi lần liếc nhìn về phía ông ta, tôi lại thấy ông ta đang nhìn tôi với ánh mắt hết sức căng thẳng. Những con đường làng ở đoạn này có vẻ không được tốt lắm vì chúng tôi cứ bị lắc lư và xóc nẩy dữ dội. Tôi cố gắng nhìn ra ngoài cửa sổ để xem mình đang đi đến đâu nhưng kính cửa là loại thủy tinh đã mài mờ nên tôi chẳng phân biệt được gì ngoại trừ một vài vệt sáng lờ mờ thỉnh thoảng băng ngang qua. Tuy vậy, cuối cùng thì đoạn đường dằn xóc cũng được thay thế bởi một lối đi rải sỏi êm ái và cỗ xe dừng lại. es_first_half: "Nos fuimos entonces, y condujimos durante al menos una hora. El coronel Lysander Stark había dicho que sólo eran siete millas, pero yo creía, por la velocidad a la que parecíamos ir, y por el tiempo que tardamos, que debían ser más de doce. Se sentó a mi lado en silencio todo el tiempo, y me di cuenta, más de una vez cuando miré en su dirección, que me estaba mirando con gran intensidad. Parece que las carreteras rurales no son muy buenas en esa parte del mundo, porque dimos unos bandazos y sacudidas terribles. Intenté mirar por las ventanillas para ver algo de dónde estábamos, pero eran de vidrio esmerilado, y no pude distinguir nada más que el borrón ocasional de una luz que pasaba. De vez en
es_second_half: cuando me arriesgaba a hacer algún comentario para romper la monotonía del viaje, pero el coronel sólo respondía con monosílabos, y la conversación pronto decaía. Por fin, sin embargo, los golpes de la carretera fueron sustituidos por la crujiente suavidad de un camino de grava, y el carruaje se detuvo. El coronel Lysander Stark se bajó de él y, mientras yo lo seguía, me arrastró a un porche que se abría ante nosotros. Bajamos, por así decirlo, del carruaje y entramos en el vestíbulo, de modo que no pude echar la más fugaz mirada a la fachada de la casa. En el instante en que crucé el umbral, la puerta se cerró de golpe detrás de nosotros, y oí débilmente el traqueteo de las ruedas mientras el carruaje se alejaba."
